responses.content: A replay of today's conference call will be available on the investor relations site for the next 24 hours.

OCI demand is extraordinary; we now have 101 cloud regions and the growth in contracted power is outpacing the region count. We expect to double capacity this year and triple it by the end of FY26, keeping power constrained only by the pace of customer deployments.

Even though OCI is scaling rapidly, we continue to automate aggressively, so our operating expenses grow slower than revenue. The cloud gross profit dollars are up double digits, and we are still seeing accelerated bookings driven by AI contracts, which further expand our RPO.

We signed more than $48 billion of contracts in the quarter, which pushed RPO to $130 billion. That backlog should keep revenue growing at least 15% into FY26 and beyond, including the upcoming Stargate tier.

We are bringing Fusion and NetSuite onto the Autonomous Database, which eliminates human labor, removes human error, and creates higher margins. Our AI data platform on Database 23ai makes private customer data immediately available to any leading AI model while keeping the data private.

Oracle is building massive GPU clusters, including the Stargate project, and we accelerate training & inferencing with our own ultra high-speed networking. We are also embedding OCI data centers inside AWS, Azure, and Google to give customers geographic coverage while we scale in-demand power regions.

questions.question_text: Congrats on the booking strength. Larry, can you expand on Stargate and why Oracle is the logical partner for that AI race project?
Can you break down how demand is unfolding across OCI public cloud, multi-cloud deals, and sovereign deployments? How durable is that traction?
How do you see the balance between AI training and inference opportunities, and where does the AI data platform plug into that?
Gross margins keep improving for OCI; can you provide an update on how automation and scale are helping margins while you keep growing capacity?
Capex is lower per dollar of IaaS revenue than hyperscalers; how should we think about the spending trajectory as bookings accelerate?
